detail.content: Creative Writing Program | New York University                      NEW YORK UNIVERSITY       ARTS AND SCIENCE       COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE       GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                                                                            Home       Faculty       Undergraduate Program       Graduate Program       Low-Residency MFA Writers Workshop in Paris       Summer Programs & Courses       Reading Series       Literary Journals       History of the Lillian Vernon Creative Writers House       Donate to the Creative Writing Program       Alumni News & Publications         “Great books are books that have two authors, the reader and the writer.”   Jonathan Safran Foer           The NYU Creative Writing Program, among the most distinguished programs in the country, is a leading national center for the study of writing and literature. The undergraduate and graduate programs provide students with an opportunity to develop their craft while working closely with some of the finest poets and novelists writing today. The Creative Writing Program now occupies a lovely townhouse on West 10th Street in the same Greenwich Village neighborhood where so many writers have lived and worked. The Lillian Vernon Creative Writers House allows writers--established and emerging--to share their work in an inspiring setting. We invite you to join a supportive and serious community of writers engaged in an exceptional program of study. Writing                            Writing                               As crucial means of critical thinking and creative expression, writing is at the heart of Gallatin’s curriculum. Students develop their academic writing skills in innovative First-Year Writing and Research Seminars , explore a variety of genres in Advanced Writing Courses , and experience writing beyond the classroom through the Gallatin Writing Program’s diverse events, publications, and civic engagement projects.   Each year, the Gallatin Writing Program hosts multiple conferences and readings by faculty, students, and guests; educates and employs four undergraduates to serve as Peer Writing Assistants in the Writing Center ; publishes the Gallatin Review , a student-edited journal of student writing and visual art; and maintains Confluence , an online platform for writing, art, and research. The Writing Program also sponsors two major civic engagement projects, the Literacy Project , and Great World Texts . The Literacy Project includes opportunities to tutor at adult literacy sites, mentor at a public high school, and edit the Literacy Review , an annual publication that compiles the best writing by adults from about 50 countries. Through Great World Texts, Gallatin undergraduates mentor public high school students in the study of a canonical text.          Read the latest from the Gallatin Writing Program in the Spring 2014 Parents Update .                    top of page                                               Faculty Profile                 Gregory Erickson       Gregory Erickson has taught at the Gallatin School since 2004, specializing in courses on modern literature, popular culture, religion, and …       more >                                                   Faculty Profile                 June Foley       June Foley's teaching and research interests are Victorian Studies, especially the novel; writing for young readers; and English (especially writing) …       more >                                                                           NYU Gallatin Footer              Gallatin School of Individualized Study     1 Washington Place     New York, NY 10003     (212) 998-7370                   A–Z Index      Directions      Contact Us      Job Opportunities               News      Support Gallatin      Feedback                         Follow us on Facebook      Follow us on Twitter      Follow us on Youtube         Follow us Instagram                 Unless otherwise noted, all content copyright NYU Gallatin. Noncredit Offerings                                                                                          The NYU School of Professional Studies Website    Faculty    Degrees    Professional Certificates    Upcoming Events        Search Courses     Credit Course     Non-Credit Course          Site    Noncredit Courses    Faculty                                                                       Humanities, Arts, and Writing                                                                                           About             Director's Message Faculty News                   Admissions                 Academics             M.S. in Professional Writing Noncredit Offerings                   Career                 Events             Art Law Day Art Crime Symposium                   Highlights             Movies 101 Modern British Drama in London Oxford University Study Program                                                     Noncredit Offerings                                            Academics ›                M.S. in Professional Writing            Noncredit Offerings                 Certificate in Appraisal Studies in Fine and Decorative Arts          Certificate in Art Business          Certificate in Art Collections Management and Display          Certificate in Art Marketing and Communications          Certificate in Arts Administration          Certificate in Book Publishing: Print and Digital          Certificate in Communication Skills          Certificate in Creative Writing          Certificate in Editing          Certificate in Journalism: Print and Digital Media          Certificate in Magazine and Website Publishing          Certificate in Screenwriting          Summer Intensive in Creative Writing                                  Ready to Proceed?           Register Now        Request Information        Events                                                                  Whether your goal is to move ahead in your career, change your professional direction, or deepen your appreciation of the humanities, arts, and writing, you’ll find a rich array of noncredit courses and certificates from which to choose. Explore subjects that stir your imagination with faculty members who are eager to share their expertise and their passion. Enjoy the intellectual stimulation of a vibrant learning community.           Ready to Proceed?        Register for Courses Now                 Noncredit Courses        Whether analyzing an artistic masterpiece, taking in a theatrical performance, or immersing yourself in a creative writing project, studying the world's greatest forms of human expression provides an ideal way to broaden your horizons. Through thought-provoking discussion and intellectual exploration, the NYU School of Professional Studies continuing education courses in the humanities and the performing arts help you to sharpen your critical thinking skills, engage in cultural discovery, and communicate with diverse audiences.   Our courses in literature, film, theater, performing arts, history, archaeology, philosophy, and religion can spark your curiosity and challenge you to view the world from a fresh perspective. Read and discuss great books. Discover the masters of American cinema or become engrossed in the work of modern European philosophers. Explore New York City's theater scene as an audience member or take to the stage in one of our many acting and performance courses.            A Selection of Courses From This Department                                              Appraisal of Historical Textiles and Clothing                                                            Great Choral Compositions in Classical Music                                                            Independent Study in Photography                                                            Literature and Film Go Back to High School                                                            Manhattan's Residential Secrets                                                            Writing Film Dialogue                                                                               View all Humanities, Arts, and Writing Noncredit Courses           Certificates        If you’re seeking an effective way to move your career forward, earning a noncredit certificate through the NYU School of Professional Studies allows you to acquire proficiency in a specific professional arena. Designed to accommodate the schedules of busy professionals, certificate programs offer in-depth knowledge and unique insights into subject matter, allowing you to gain significant expertise and industry-specific skills. This powerful credential can help you to achieve your career goals and greatly enhance your résumé.
